property.name: builtTimeline
property.value: {"nodes":[{"title":"Invasion by Genghis Khan","file":"1454439764056","year":"1219","desc":"Genghis Khan conquers Afghanistan, ending six centuries of rule by small Islamic dynasties. He brings Afghanistan into his empire and rules until his death in 1227.","attribution":null},{"title":"Timurid Rule","file":"1454441132256","year":"1405","desc":"Timur, who conquered Afghanistan in the 14th century, dies. His successors, the Timurids, continue to rule the region until 1507. Their rule marks a time of peace and prosperity.","attribution":null},{"title":"Anglo-Afghan Wars","file":"1454441842908","year":"1839","desc":"A series of three wars between Afghanistan and the British begins. The British seek to ward off Russian influence and fight Persian rule in Afghanistan.","attribution":null},{"title":"Durand Line","file":"1454442298594","year":"1893","desc":"The Durand line is drawn during the Anglo-Afghan Wars to separate Afghanistan from British-ruled India. When Pakistan is established decades later, the line will mark the border between Pakistan and Afghanistan.","attribution":null},{"title":"Afghan Victory","file":"1454449759987","year":"1919","desc":"Afghanistan claims victory after a third Anglo-Afghan War. Its friendship with the newly established Soviet Union is formally recognized.","attribution":null},{"title":"Monarchy","file":"1454444348290","year":"1923","desc":"Afghanistan is ruled as a monarchy until 1973. Mohammad Zahir Shah, the last king of Afghanistan, rules under stable conditions for 40 years. After a drought and famine in the 1970s, Zahir Shah is deposed in a coup and goes into exile.","attribution":null},{"title":"Daud Khan","file":"1454444247527","year":"1973","desc":"Mohammad Daud Khan, the king's brother-in-law, declares Afghanistan a republic and assumes the presidency. He attempts reforms and tries to scale back Soviet influence. He is assasinated in 1978, leading to further instability and unrest.","attribution":null},{"title":"Soviet Invasion","file":"1455920354866","year":"1979","desc":"Soviet troops invade Afghanistan. Their invasion is followed by the Soviet-Afghan War, in which around a million people die and millions more are left as refugees. The war lasts until 1989.","attribution":null},{"title":"Soviet Withdrawal","file":"1455920482891","year":"1989","desc":"Throughout the 1980s, the mujahideen, comprised of Afghan men and Arab foreigners, fight to establish a religious regime in Afghanistan and overthrow secular Soviet influences. In 1989, the Soviets withdraw from Afghanistan. ","attribution":null},{"title":"Collapse of the Government","file":"1454449656317","year":"1992","desc":"The Afghan government collapses, leaving control of the country in the hands of rogue fighters, war lords, and disorganized militias.","attribution":null},{"title":"Rise of the Taliban","file":"1454447777754","year":"1994","desc":"The Taliban begin organizing in Kandahar. They fight local warlords and take control of Kabul in 1996. They enforce a strict interpretation of Islamic law, use stoning and amputation as punshiments, impose severe restrictions on women, and function as a safe haven for Islamic extremists.","attribution":null},{"title":"U.S. Involvement","file":"1454449495970","year":"2001","desc":"Following the 9/11 attacks, U.S. forces invade Afghanistan. The Taliban government is toppled, and a new constitution is ratified in 2004. Many Afghans leave the country due to instability.","attribution":"-"},{"title":"U.S. Mission Completion","file":"1454448971873","year":"2014","desc":"After years of conducting counterinsurgency activity in Afghanistan, the U.S. formally completes its mission.","attribution":null}]}
